0.text:
I know that many people from across the political
spectrum feel that we don’t have the space,

5.text:
the infrastructure or the money to feed any
more mouths in this country. People here feel

10.text:
squeezed - mortgages and rents are bleeding
us dry, we’re using foodbanks… How can

15.text:
we take on any more? Well, one could argue
that we are taking in the wrong sort of immigrants

21.text:
to this country. The ones with money. The
ones who are buying up all the property in

26.text:
London and the south, and artificially inflating
house prices, meaning that normal people can’t

30.text:
afford to live here. And the trouble with
people with a lot of money is that they are

34.text:
really awfully good at holding on to it - forget
trickledown. These people employ fleets of

39.text:
accountants and lawyers who keep all their
money in the Independent Economic Republic

46.text:
of Santa VisaDelta, and they barely spend
a penny over here. London has become like

50.text:
Wales or Cornwall, with people breezing in
for the weekend with their metaphorical Volvos

55.text:
full of shopping. No, the kind of immigrants
we want are the poor ones. The ones who need

60.text:
to work. Who can’t hide their money, but
have to spend it. Who don’t get fancy tax

65.text:
concessions. Just an idea, but how about we
were to house all the people arriving on Lesbos

71.text:
in all the vacant properties owned by Greek
shipping magnates in London? ‘Oh, yeah,

75.text:
but that’s not how it works, and there’s
a housing crisis, and we’d have to fork

79.text:
out for these people’s accommodation, and…’
well, not according to an article by Jonathan

85.text:
Friedland in the Guardian which says there’s
EU money available, specific funding for housing

92.text:
immigrants in private property. So we’re
entitled to that. ‘What about the food?

96.text:
Yeah? What about the food? YEAH?’ 15 million
tonnes of food gets wasted in the UK every

101.text:
year. The equivalent of a can of beans for
every man, woman and child here every day.

106.text:
Plenty for a few hundred thousand immigrants.
Some of that waste - well, half - is our responsibility,

111.text:
and honestly, as someone who has eaten fizzy
hummus many times and not died, come on, but

116.text:
half gets wasted by the supermarkets before
it even arrives in the stores. Why not hook

121.text:
up immigrants with amazing charities and movements
like FareShare and feedbackglobal.org, who

126.text:
organise gleaning days. These are days when
volunteers go to farmers’ fields and, with

131.text:
their blessing, pick all the crops that are
no longer economically viable to harvest.

135.text:
So aggressive are the supermarkets with their
pricing that farmers now regularly leave whole

139.text:
crops to spoil, because they will lose money
if they harvest them. This is insane. With

144.text:
immigrants you’ll have willing workers,
and a job to do. Does this make more sense?

149.text:
‘Er, no, it doesn’t Jake, because you
didn’t think of THIS, actually, so, er,

153.text:
you’re a dick’ - I do welcome your thoughts
and ideas on any of this in the comments section

157.text:
below… In the meantime, why not subscribe
- I’m doing five new videos a week, and

161.text:
they won’t all be all ranty like this…
Ok. Comments. Go!
